name: Gastric
question1: Discuss the phases of gastric secretion (3)?  Describe the functions of the hormones involved? (4)
contents:
Control of Secretions

Secretion occurs in three phases:


  • Cephalic
  • Thought/sight/taste/smell of food, resulting in vagal-mediated stimulus to release gastrin.
  • Accounts for ~30% of production.
  • Gastric
  • Stretch of the stomach stimulates HCl secretion and gastrin release.
  • once the pH reaches 2 gastrin begins to exert a negative feedback effect.
  • Accounts for ~50% of production.
  • Intestinal
  • A drop in pH of the proximal duodenum releases secretin to stimulate the exocrine pancreas.
  • Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP), which inhibits further gastric secretions and motility
  • Secretin, which inhibits further gastric secretions
  • Cholecystokinin (CCK) which inhibits stomach emptying.


Approximately 1L of saliva is produced by the parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands each day. (lubrication, digestion, neutralisaiton of acid, antibacterial)

Hormones

  • Gastin
  • release stimulated by: cephalic phase, stomach distension, proteins in stomach
  • actions : increases secretion of gastric juices, increases motility, constricts LOS, relaxes pyloric and ileocaecal sphincters
  • GIP
  • release stimulated by: fatty acids in small intestine
  • actions : increases insulin release, inhibits secretion of gastric juices, slows gastric emptying
  • Secretin
  • release stimulated by: acidic chyme in small intestine
  • actions : stiulates contraction of gallbladder to release bile, stimulates release of pancratic enzymes, augments effects of CCK
  • CCK
  • release stimulated by: amino acids and fatty acids in small intestine
  • actions : stimulates contraction of gallbladder to release bile, stimulates release of pancreatic enzymes, induces feeling of satiety, inhibits gastric emptying, enchances actions of secretin.
question2: Draw a gastric parietal cell with its mechanism of action and its receptors.
contents3:
• Structure, usually made up of circular muscle, that surrounds the opening of a hallow organ or body and constricts to close it.
  • Sphincters can be:
  • anatomical, where they are clearly different from the surrounding tissue eg the anus, or functional where the histological distinction is not so clear.
  • can be under voluntary or involuntary control.
  • Sphincters in the GI tract (6)
  • Upper oesophageal (C5-6 vertebrae)
  • made up of cricopharyngeal part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle
  • Lower oesophageal (also called the cardiac sphincter)
  • functional sphincter found at the junction between the non-keratinized squamous epithelium of the oesophagus and the simple columnar epithelium of the stomach.
  • its function is to prevent reflux of the acidic stomach contents into the oesophagus and so it is constricted at rest and has a pressure of 15-20mmHg.
  • Pyloric
  • anatomical sphincter
  • Sphincter of oddi
  • Ileocaecal
  • Anus
question5: TPN - what are the indications?  Describe the nutritional content.
contents5:
Where possible the enteral route should also be used.

TPN should be considered where:

  • Anticipation of undernutrition
  • TPN may be indicated for severely undernourished patients unable to ingest large volumes of oral feed prior to surgery,
  • Patients with disorders requiring complete GI rest eg UC or pancreatitis
  • Post-operative patient in whom enteral feeding has not been possible or failed.


Basic adult requirements for TPN

  • Water 30-40mls/kg/day
  • Energy :
  • Medical patient 30kCal/kg/day (eg 30x60kg = 1800kCal/day)
  • Surgical patient 30-45kCal/kg/day
  • Hypercatabolic
  • Amino acids: Medical 1g/day Post-operative 2g/day
  • Essential fatty acids -
  • Minerals - Acetate/Calcium/Chloride/Copper/Magnesium
  • Potassium, Selenium/Sodium/Zinc


From Starvation page

Stores: Energy stored as carbohydrate, protein and triglycerides.

  • 1600kCal as glycogen.
  • 24,000kcal in mobilisable protein
  • 135,000kcal in triglycerides.
